Title: Accounting Principles I
Description: This course introduces basic accounting procedures for  analyzing, recording, and summarizing financial transactions, adjusting and closing the financial records at the end of the accounting cycle, and preparing financial records at the end of the accounting cycle, and preparing financial statements.

Title: Accounting Principles II
Description: This course emphasizes managerial accounting theory and practice in basic accounting and procedures for cost accounting, budgeting, cost-volume analysis, and financial statement analysis. Prerequisite:  ACC 101

Title: Accounting for Entrepreneurs
Description: A study of the principles of financial accounting, managerial accounting, taxes, bookkeeping, accounting systems, and record keeping essential to starting and operating a new business enterprise.

Title: Individual Tax Procedures
Description: This course is a study of the basic income tax structure from the standpoint of the individual, including the preparation of individual income tax returns.

Title: Small Business Software
Description: This course includes the use of current integrated software suitable for small business operations.

Title: Accounting Applications
Description: This course introduces microcomputer accounting using data base software and/or electronic spreadsheets. Prerequisite:  ACC 101

Title: Medical Terminology
Description: This course covers medical terms, including roots, prefixes, and suffixes, with emphasis on spelling, definition, and pronunciation.

Title: Medical Vocabulary
Description: This course introduces the fundamental principles of medical terminology and includes a survey of human anatomy and physiology.

Title: Health Careers
Description: This course provides information on various health careers to include job responsibility and personal and educational requirements as well as an overview of the health care system with its unique nomenclature and delivery of care.

Title: Nutrition
Description: This course is a study of nutrition and diet therapy as related to healthcare.

Title: Patient Care Relations
Description: This course includes a study of the psychological and emotional effect of illness, hospitalization and recuperation upon the patient, others, and healthcare providers.

Title: Nurse Assisting
Description: This course includes a study of concepts required to assist in the care of patients.

Title: Responding to Emergencies
Description: The course is a study of emergency care procedures utilizing first aid and CPR principles and recognizes the need for more contact hours for teaching this course.

Title: Health Care Skill I
Description: This course includes basic skills needed to care for residents in a long-term care setting. 183 Prerequisite: AHS 104 and AHS 119

Title: Health Care Procedures
Description: This course includes a study of fundamental health skills related to the patient/client in all of life's stages.

Title: Long-Term Care
Description: This course emphasizes the basic skills needed to care for residents in the long-term care setting. Students will apply practical use of these skills through clinical experiences in a long-term care facility. Prerequisite: AHS 104 and AHS 119

Title: Keyboarding
Description: This course focuses on the mastery of keyboarding.

Title: Document Formatting
Description: This course emphasizes speed, accuracy and developing document formatting skills using keyboarding competencies. Prerequisite: AOT 105

Title: Introduction to Machine Transcription
Description: This is an introductory machine transcription course which is designed to provide experience in transcribing documents from dictation equipment. Prerequisite: AOT 105 and AOT 163

Title: Professional Development
Description: This course emphasizes development of personal and professional skills required of an office worker in areas such as projecting a professional image, job seeking skills, office etiquette, ethics and time and stress management.

Title: Office Communications
Description: This course develops proficiency in proofreading and other specialized applications of communications in the office environment. Prerequisite: AOT 105

Title: Data Entry
Description: This course introduces data entry techniques.

Title: Office Procedures I
Description: This is an introductory course to a variety of office procedures and tasks using business equipment, systems and procedures.

Title: Word Processing
Description: This course introduces the concepts of word processing. Prerequisite: AOT 105

Title: Information Processing Applications
Description: This course emphasizes applications and features of information processing software. Prerequisites: AOT 105 and AOT 163

Title: Document Production
Description: This course emphasizes the production of documents found in typical business offices. The major focus is on productivity and excellence in document production. Prerequisite: AOT 110

Title: Office Simulation
Description: This course integrates a wide variety of skills and knowledge through practical work experiences in a simulated office environment. 184

Title: Art History and Appreciation
Description: This is an introductory course to the history and appreciation of the visual arts, including the elements and principles of the art media and the historical styles and movements associated with Western art.

Title: Computer Graphics I
Description: This course is a study of the fundamentals of Computer Assisted Graphic Design.

Title: Computer Imagery
Description: This course covers the use of the computer as a tool to create images that addresses the needs of the visual communication field.

Title: Multimedia Techniques
Description: This course is an introduction to the production of current audio-visual media.

Title: Multimedia Presentations
Description: This course covers a study of multimedia techniques culminating in a presentation.

Title: Principles of Finance
Description: This is an introductory course to the field of finance. The monetary and credit system are examined along with how the demand for funds is met in both the public and private sector.

Title: Barbering Fundamentals
Description: This course is an introduction to the barbering profession, including the care and use of equipment and implements.

Title: Facial Care
Description: This course is a study of the anatomy of the head, face and neck and the proper care and treatment of the face, including shaving techniques.

Title: Shampoo and Conditioners
Description: This course is a study of shampoos and conditioners and their uses in relationship to hair structure and texture.

Title: Fundamentals of Hair Cutting
Description: This course is a study of fundamentals of haircutting including the use of the clippers, shears, and razors.

Title: Hair and Scalp Care I
Description: This course is a study of various disorders of the skin, hair, and scalp.

Title: Hair and Scalp Care II
Description: This course is a study of the various methods of treating disorders of the hair and scalp.

Title: Chemical Processing of Hair
Description: This course is a study of the techniques used in the chemical processing of the hair, including the action of chemical products, safety precautions, and the use of various implements.

Title: Barber Shop Management
Description: This course is a study of the method used in operating an effective barber shop, including facilities and equipment management, record keeping, advertising, policies, and procedures.

Title: Barbering Clinical Practice I
Description: This course is an integration of barbering skills in a simulated salon environment.

Title: Barbering Clinical Practice II
Description: This course is an integration of barbering skills in a simulated salon environment to provide additional practical hours in skill development. 185

Title: Introduction to Building Construction
Description: This course is an introduction to residential and light commercial construction, construction terms, tools of the trade and their safe use.

Title: Fundamentals of Building Construction
Description: This course is a study of framing for residential and light commercial buildings.

Title: Construction Site Layout
Description: This course covers location and layout of building corners, elevation, and the use of appropriate tools.

Title: Tool Usage and Safety
Description: This course covers tool skills and their safe use in construction.

Title: Blueprint Reading and Specifications
Description: This course is an introductory study of construction plans and specifications and how they represent finished buildings.

Title: Residential Wiring
Description: This course is a study of wiring methods and practices used in residential application.

Title: Introduction to Residential Plumbing
Description: This course covers plumbing theory as it relates to residential construction.

Title: Residential Plumbing
Description: This course is a study of the plumbing methods and practices used in residential application.

Title: Construction Building Code
Description: This course is a study of local, state, and national building code requirements as they apply to residential and commercial construction.

Title: Biological Science I
Description: This course is the first of a sequence introducing biology. Topics include the scientific method, basic biochemistry, cell structure and function, cell physiology, cell reproduction and development, Mendelian genetics, population genetics, natural selection, evolution, and ecology.

Title: Biological Science II
Description: This is a continuation of introductory biology which includes classification of organisms and structural and  functional considerations of all kingdoms (particularly major phyla as well as viruses). Vertebrate animals and vascular plants are emphasized. Pre-requisite:  BIO 101

Title: Basic Anatomy & Physiology
Description: This course is a basic integrated study of the structure and function of the human body.

Title: CAREER OPTIONS FOR HEALT PROFESSIONALS
Description: This course is designed for students interested in a health-related career as an opportunity to explore various careers in the health professions and their roles in the healthcare system in the United States. Students will understand how the social determinants of health contribute to health inequities in health care and public health and assess research evidence presented in the health sciences. This course will also cover topics such as career planning, study skills, time management, team building, and other topics to facilitate student success in future health-related careers.

Title: Human Anatomy and Physiology I
Description: This course is the first in a sequence of courses, including an intensive coverage of the body as an integrated whole.  All body systems are studied.

Title: Human Anatomy and Physiology II
Description: 186 This course is a continuation of a sequence of courses, including coverage of the body as an integrated whole.  All body systems are studied. Pre-requisite:  BIO 210

Title: Bakeshop Production
Description: This course covers the applications of fundamentals and principles of basic baking. Emphasis is placed on skill development for quality commercial bakery products.

Title: Introduction to Business
Description: This is a study of the nature of business activity in relation to the economic society, including how a business is owned, organized, managed and controlled.

Title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
Description: This course is an introduction to the concept of entrepreneurship and the exploration of traditional and nontraditional business ventures.  Students will identify their entrepreneurship type, and brainstorm personal interests, goals, and talents for the development of the business idea.

Title: Business Plan
Description: This course involves the development of a sound business plan for a small business idea.  Students will assess the strengths and weaknesses of a business idea, develop a marketing plan, prepare financial projections, and identify and evaluate potential funding sources for their business.

Title: Business Law I
Description: This course is a study of legal procedures, law and society, classifications and systems of law, the tribunals administering justice and their actions, contracts, sales, transfer of titles, rights and duties of the parties, conditions, and warranties.

Title: Business Communications
Description: This course covers the application of communication skills to situations routinely encountered in business environments.

Title: Introduction to E-Commerce in Business
Description: This course is the study of electronic commerce and the operations and applications from the business perspective. Emphasis is placed on business concepts and strategies and how they apply to the process of buying and selling goods and services online.

Title: Business Statistics
Description: This course is a study of statistical methods related to business, including descriptive statistics, probability, binomial and normal distributions, and hypothesis testing.

Title: General Organic & Biochemistry
Description: This course is a study of the fundamental principles of chemistry, including atomic and molecular structure, common substances and reactions, introduction to organic chemistry and biochemistry.

Title: College Chemistry  I
Description: This is the first course in a sequence which includes the following topics: atomic and molecular structure,  nomenclature and equations, properties, reactions and states of matter, stoichiometry, gas laws, solutions and equilibria.

Title: College Chemistry II
Description: This course is a continuation of the study of atomic and molecular structure, nomenclature and equations, properties, reactions and states of matter, stoichiometry, gas laws, solutions, and equilibria. Pre-requisite:  CHM 110

Title: Computer Integrated Manufacturing
Description: This course is a comprehensive overview of the total manufacturing operation. 187

Title: College Orientation
Description: This course may include selected topics such as career planning, study skills, stress management, tutoring, group guidance, and other subjects to facilitate student success.

Title: College Skills
Description: This course includes selected topics such as career planning, study skills, stress management, tutoring, group guidance, and other subjects to facilitate student success.

Title: Skills for College
Description: This course is designed to enhance the skills of entering freshmen to facilitate their ability to succeed in the college environment. The course topics include student/instructor expectations, time management, library/computer orientation, listening/notetaking, studying for success, learning styles/personality types, and diversity and differences on campus.

Title: E-Learning Success
Description: This course introduces the online learning management system, basic computer skills, information literacy, time management skills, and learning resources to enhance student success in an electronic learning  environment.

Title: Fundamentals of Cosmetology
Description: This is an introductory course to the fundamentals of  professional ethics, hygiene, good grooming, and salesmanship as they relate to the practice of the salon.

Title: Facials and Make-up
Description: This is an introductory course of the procedures for various skin treatments, including anatomy, chemistry, and safety.

Title: Nail Care
Description: This course is a study of nail structure and manicuring  techniques, including anatomy, chemistry, and safety.

Title: Scalp and Hair Care
Description: This course is a study of the structure and composition of hair, including the analysis and treatment of certain conditions of the hair and scalp.

Title: Hair Shaping
Description: This course is an introductory course to the techniques of hair-shaping. Emphasis is given to the correct use and  safety of implements, proper hair sectioning, and various techniques used in hair design in relationship to body structure.

Title: Hair Styling I
Description: This course is a study of the fundamentals of hair design, including principles, techniques, safety precautions, and chemistry.

Title: Salon Management
Description: This course is a study of salon management, including rules, regulations, and codes governing the practice of Cosmetology.

Title: Chemical Hair Waving
Description: This course is a study of methods of permanently waving the hair, including product, chemistry, and safety.

Title: Chemical Hair Relaxing
Description: This course is a study of methods of chemically relaxing the basic structure of hair, including product, chemistry, and safety.

Title: Hair Coloring
Description: This course is a study of the science and art of coloring the hair, including methods, procedures, safety pre- cautions, and chemistry. 188

Title: Hair Lightening
Description: This course is a study of the lightening of hair, including methods, procedures, safety precautions and chemistry.

Title: Cosmetology Clinical Practice I
Description: This course is an integration of cosmetology skills in a simulated salon environment.

Title: Cosmetology Clinical Practice II
Description: This course is an integration of cosmetology skills in a simulated salon environment.

Title: Computer Language
Description: This course covers a high-level computer language, programming concepts, and applications.

Title: Introduction to Computers
Description: This course covers basic computer history, theory and  applications, including word processing, spreadsheet, data bases, and the operating system.

Title: Introduction to Information Technology
Description: This course is a study of basic computer components and peripherals, basic computer functions, i/o concepts, storage concepts, data communications, distributed processing, and programming language concepts.

Title: Computers and Programming
Description: This course introduces computer concepts and programming. Topics include basic concepts of computer architecture, files, memory, and input/output devices. Programming is done in a modern high -level language.

Title: COBOL Programming I
Description: This course introduces the nature and use of the common business-oriented language – COBOL. Prerequisite: CPT 170

Title: Introduction to Online Learning
Description: This course will familiarize students with the online learning environment. Topics will include using course management tools, conducting online research effectively, and troubleshooting technical problems.

Title: Consumer Applications II
Description: This course is an introduction to the basic concepts and techniques of microcomputer application software for personal computing needs. Topics include compiling and storing information, letter writing, and desktop publishing fundamentals for newsletters and bulletins.

Title: Programming Logic and Design
Description: This course examines problem-solving techniques applied to program design. Topics include a variety of documentation techniques as means of solution presentation. Prerequisite :  CPT 101

Title: Microcomputer Applications
Description: This course introduces microcomputer applications software, including word processing, databases, spread-sheets, graphs, and their integration.

Title: Microcomputer Spreadsheets
Description: This course introduces the use of spreadsheet software on the microcomputer. Topics include creating, editing, using formulas, using functions, and producing graphs.

Title: Mobile App Development
Description: This course is a study of mobile app development. Students will learn to develop and test applications designed for mobile devices such as tablet computers and/or smartphones. Topics include building views, program code  development, and application testing on a device simulator. 189

Title: Visual Basic Programming
Description: This course focuses on Windows programming using Visual Basic to create graphical user interfaces. The course examines forms, controls, graphical controls, loops, control arrays, database and traditional file processing, and application class scheduling.

Title: COBOL Programming II
Description: This course emphasizes file maintenance and tables using advanced concepts in COBOL. Prerequisite:  CPT  115

Title: C Programming I
Description: This introductory course in C programming emphasizes the designing, coding, testing and debugging of C programs involving input/output operations, data types, storage classes, decision structures, looping, functions, preprocessor directives, arrays and simple pointers. Prerequisite:  CPT 168

Title: C Programming II
Description: This course is a study of using advanced techniques for programming with the C language, including structures, advanced pointers, string manipulations, bit operations, and C Library Functions. Prerequisite:  CPT 234

Title: Database
Description: This course introduces data base models and the fundamentals of data base design. Topics include data base structures, data base processing, and application programs which access a data base. Prerequisite:  CPT 170

Title: Operating Systems
Description: This course examines the theory of operating systems and how the operating system theory is implemented in current operating systems. Prerequisite:  CPT 170

Title: Systems and Procedures
Description: This course covers the techniques of system analysis, design, development, and implementation. Prerequisite:  CPT 168

Title: Information Systems Security
Description: This course is the study of the protection of information and equipment in computer systems. Topics include all aspects of systems protection, including physical security, hardware, software, and communications security.  Addresses technical, legal, and ethical issues.

Title: Introduction to Criminal Justice
Description: This course includes an overview of the functions and responsibilities of agencies involved in the administration of justice to include police organizations, court systems, correctional systems, and juvenile justice agencies.

Title: Introduction to Security
Description: This course includes an introduction to the philosophy and application of security. The protection of personnel, facilities, and other assets as well as administrative, legal, and technical problems of loss prevention and control are analyzed.

Title: Criminal Law I
Description: This course covers the development of criminal law in America. The course also covers the basic elements of  specific criminal offenses, criminal defenses, and various legal principles upon which criminal law is established. 190

Title: Constitutional Law
Description: This course covers the analysis of the historical development of the U.S. Constitution and the relationship of rights contained therein to the State and to the individual. The application of the Bill of Rights to Federal and State Systems is examined.

Title: Criminology
Description: This course is a study of the various theories of criminal causation and control, the identification of criminal typologies, and the reaction of society to crime and criminals.

Title: Police Administration
Description: This course is the study of the organization, administration, and management of law enforcement agencies.

Title: Juvenile Delinquency
Description: This course includes a survey of the sociological, biological, and psychological theories involved in juvenile delinquency, modern trends in prevention, and treatment.

Title: Ethics in Criminal Justice
Description: This course is a study of the application of ethical theories to the criminal justice profession.

Title: Criminal Investigation I
Description: This course is a study of the fundamentals of interviewing witnesses and interrogating suspects.  Different methods of conducting crime scene searches and methods used in investigating various crimes are studied in this course.

Title: Criminal Evidence
Description: This course is a study of the established rules of evidence from arrest to release in the administration of criminal justice.

Title: Correctional Systems
Description: This course is an introduction to aspects of the correctional function in criminal justice, including organization, process, procedures, and clients incarcerated and on conditional release.

Title: Probation, Pardon and Parole
Description: This course is a study of the development, organization,  operation, and results of systems of probation and parole as substitutes for incarceration. The philosophy and methods of treatment of offenders and the operational problems and activities of the probation/parole officer are studied in the course.

Title: Special Problems in Criminal Justice
Description: This course examines issues within the criminal justice community/ profession which are of special concern to students and practitioners because of such elements as timelines, local concern, legalistic, and/or other dynamic factors of such issues.

Title: Principles of Food Production I
Description: This is an introductory course in food preparation, including kitchen safety and sanitation.  Emphasis is placed on the practical  presentation of simple foods, terminology, and techniques of preparing nutritious, quality food.

Title: Principles of Food Production II
Description: This course is a study of the preparation of food categories such as sauces, salads, baked products, meats, poultry, vegetables, etc.  Special attention is given to presentation and garnishing.

Title: Nutrition
Description: This course is a study of general nutritional needs of the life cycle, including carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals. Practical applications for the food service professional are emphasized.

Title: Introduction to Culinary Arts
Description: This survey course introduces students to the world of culinary arts. Students will be exposed to culinary history, culinary organizations and branches of the culinary field that offer different opportunities in the profession. 191

Title: Hospitality Sanitation
Description: This course is a study of local, state and national regulations governing sanitary food handling practices.

Title: Buffet Organization
Description: This course is a study of the principles and applications of how to plan, organize, and setup a complete buffet. Topics include forced meats, ice carvings, and garnishes.

Title: Menu Planning
Description: This course is a study of the principles of menu planning and design with application of basic nutrition, organization plans, and record-keeping techniques.

Title: Introduction to Early Childhood
Description: This course includes an overview of the history, theories, and curriculum models of early education.   Emphasis is on current trends/issues, with a review of state/national regulations. Characteristics of quality programs and professional teachers are explored in the course.

Title: Growth and Development I
Description: This course is an extensive study of philosophies and  theories of growth and development of infants/toddlers.  Focus is on "total" development of the child, with emphasis on physical, social, emotional, cognitive, and nutritional areas. Developmental tasks and appropriate activities are explored in the course.

Title: Guidance/Classroom Management
Description: This course is an overview of developmentally appropriate, effective guidance and classroom management techniques for the teacher of young children. A positive proactive approach is stressed in the course.

Title: Exceptional Children
Description: This course includes an overview of special needs children and their families. Emphasis is on the prevalence of disorders, treatment modalities, community resources serving exceptional children, the teacher's role in mainstreaming and early identification, and on federal legislation affecting exceptional children.

Title: Family and Community Relations
Description: This course is an overview of techniques and materials for promoting effective family/program partnerships to foster positive child development. Emphasis is on availability and accessibility of community resources and on developing appropriate communication skills.

Title: Administration and Supervision
Description: This course is a study of the role and responsibilities of an early childhood administrator. Special focus is on program monetary matter, space management, curriculum, health and food services, and relations among the public, staff, and parents.

Title: Language Arts
Description: This course provides an overview of age appropriate developmental language arts activities.  The curriculum consists of four broad interrelated areas like speaking, listening, writing, and reading of young children.  This also includes planning, implementation, and evaluation of media, methods, techniques, and equipment. Emphasis on activities connected to the diverse backgrounds of children are included.

Title: Creative Experience
Description: In this course the importance of creativity and independence in creative expression are stressed. A variety of age- appropriate media, methods, techniques, and equipment are utilized. Students plan, implement, and evaluate instructional activities.

Title: Science and Math Concepts
Description: This course includes an overview of pre-number and science concepts developmentally appropriate for young children. Emphasis is on the planning, implementation, and evaluation of developmentally appropriate activities utilizing a variety of methods and materials. 192

Title: Health, Safety and Nutrition
Description: This course covers a review of health and safety practices recommended for childcare and includes  information on common diseases and health problems. Certification preparation is provided in pediatric safety, CPR and first aid. Guidelines and information on nutrition and developmentally appropriate activities also are studied in the course.

Title: Principles of Ethics and Leadership in Early Care and Education
Description: This course includes an overview of historical views on  leadership, and issues and challenges of leadership in early care and education. Emphasis is on current trends and issues. This course also includes a review of ethical principles as they relate to children, families, colleagues, and the community and society. Characteristics of professional teachers in early care and education are also explored in the course.

Title: Growth and Development II
Description: This course is an in-depth study of preschool children  growing and developing in today’s world.  Focus is on “total” development of the child with emphasis on physical, social, emotional, cognitive, and nutritional areas of development. Developmental tasks and appropriate activities are explored in the course. Prerequisite: ECD 102

Title: Methods and Materials
Description: This course includes an overview of developmentally- appropriate methods and materials for planning, implementing, and evaluating environments. Emphasis is on integrating divergent activities in each curriculum area.

Title: Supervised Field Experience I
Description: This course includes emphasis on planning, implementing, and evaluating schedule programs, age-appropriate methods, materials, activities and environments of early childhood principles and practices.

Title: Macroeconomics
Description: This course includes the study of fundamental principles and policies of a modern economy to include markets and prices, national income accounting, cycles, employment theory and fiscal policy, banking, and monetary controls, and the government’s role in economic decisions and growth.

Title: Microeconomics
Description: This course includes the study of the behavior of  households and firms, including supply and demand,  elasticity, price/input in different market structures, pricing of resources, regulations, and comparative advantage and trade.

Title: Electrical Circuits I
Description: This course is a study of direct and altering currents, covering resistance and impedance in series, parallel, and series - parallel circuits using Ohm's law, Kirchhoff's laws, and basic circuit theorems. Circuits are analyzed using mathematics and verified using electrical instruments.

Title: Electrical Circuits II
Description: This course is a continuation in electrical circuits, including advanced network theorems. Circuits are analyzed using mathematics and verified using electrical instruments.

Title: Active Devices
Description: This course is a study of semiconductor theory and principles, diodes and diode circuits, transistors, transistor circuits, and other components. Circuits are modeled, constructed, and tested.

Title: Digital Circuits
Description: This course is a study of number systems, basic logic gates, Boolean Algebra, logic optimization, flip-flops, counters, and registers. Circuits are modeled, constructed, and tested. EET  233  Control Systems This course is a study of open and closed loop control system operations, elements, and applications.  Various industrial model programmable logic controllers are used to simulate application to flexible manufacturing systems. 193

Title: Engineering Technology Applications and Programming
Description: This course covers the development and use of computer programs to solve engineering technology problems.

Title: Statics and Strength Materials
Description: This course covers external and internal forces in structures and/or machines, including conditions of equilibrium, systems of force, moments of inertia and friction. It also covers the stress/strain relationship in materials.

Title: Introduction to CAD
Description: This course covers the operation of a computer aided drafting system. The course includes interaction with a CAD station to produce technical drawings.

Title: Introduction to Electronic Servicing
Description: This is an introductory course in electronic servicing, emphasizing servicing and shop procedures.

Title: Servicing Techniques
Description: This course is a study of practical experience in the servicing of electronic equipment, including working in a service shop environment or situation.

Title: Microcomputer Repair
Description: This course includes servicing of popular microcomputers, disk drives, modems, and other peripheral devices

Title: Developmental English
Description: This course is an intensive review of grammar and usage; mechanics of punctuation, spelling, and capitalization; sentence structure; and writing, editing, and revising are emphasized in this course along with a study of different models of writing for a variety of rhetorical situations.

Title: English Composition I
Description: This is a (college transfer) course in which the following topics are presented: a study of composition in conjunction with appropriate literary selections, with frequent theme assignments to reinforce effective writing. A  review of  standard usage and the basic techniques of research are also presented.

Title: English Composition II
Description: This is a (college transfer) course in which the following topics are presented: development of writing skills through logical organization, effective style, literary analysis, and research. An introduction to literary genre is also included.

Title: Technical Communications
Description: This course is a study of various technical communications, such as definitions, processes, instructions, descriptions, and technical reports.

Title: Business Communications
Description: This course presents a comprehensive survey of business English usage and communication skills.

Title: American Literature I
Description: This course is a study of American literature from the  Colonial Period to the Civil War.

Title: American Literature II
Description: This course is a study of American literature from the Civil War to the present.

Title: English Literature I
Description: This is a (college transfer) course in which the following topics are presented: the study of English literature from the Old English Period to the Romantic Period with emphasis on major writers and periods.

Title: English Literature II
Description: This is a (college transfer) course in which the following topics are presented: the study of English literature from the Romantic Period to the present with emphasis on major   writers and periods. 194

Title: World Literature I
Description: This course is a study of masterpieces of world literature in translation from the ancient world to the sixteenth century.

Title: World Literature II
Description: This course is a study of masterpieces of world literature in translation from the seventeenth century to the present.

Title: African American Literature
Description: This course is a critical study of African American literature examined from historical, social, and psychological perspectives.

Title: Western Civilization to 1689
Description: This course is a survey of Western Civilization from ancient times to 1689, including the major political, social, economic, and intellectual factors shaping Western cultural tradition.

Title: Western Civilization Post-1689
Description: This course is a survey of Western Civilization form 1689 to the present, including major political, social, economic, and intellectual factors which shape the modern Western world.

Title: African American History
Description: This course is a study of the history of African Americans, including African heritage, American history, and significant contributions by individuals.

Title: American History:  Discovery to 1877
Description: This course is a survey of U.S. history from discovery to 1877. This course includes political, social, economic, and intellectual developments during this period.

Title: American History:  1877 to Present
Description: This course is a survey of U.S. history from 1877 to the present. This course includes political, social, economic, and intellectual developments during this period.

Title: Food Service Management
Description: This course is a study of operational food service management. Topics include food service operations, layout, and design of restaurants, marketing and sales promotion, food and beverage procedures, and public  relations.

Title: Introduction to Human Services
Description: This course covers an overview of the field of human services. Role responsibilities, problems, boundaries, and strategies of human service workers are included.

Title: Services for The Elderly
Description: This course is a study of services available for older adults (55 and over), including health, social, recreational, financial, and educational services.

Title: Activity Therapy
Description: This course is a study of activity programs for human services settings. Actual activity projects for various settings are developed by the students.

Title: Supervised Field Placement I
Description: This course includes work experience assignments by students in selected Human Services agencies.

Title: Supervised Field Placement II
Description: This course includes work assignments in selected Human Service agencies.

Title: Human Behavior and Social Environment
Description: This course provides an overview of the human life cycle from birth to old age, focusing on the psychosocial implications for each stage of development. The student will be able to analyze why people interact in society the way they do. 195

Title: Introduction to Social Work
Description: This course includes a general introduction to social work, including history, philosophy, organization, methods, and settings with emphasis on rehabilitation and other community services.

Title: Gerontology
Description: This course is a survey of the physical, social, and mental changes that occur as a person ages. The related problems and current programs, designed for people aged 55 and over, are studied in the course.

Title: Death and Dying
Description: This course is a study of the issues of death and dying. Stages of dying, dealing with dying, dealing with sudden death, and grief are covered in the course.

Title: Alcohol and Drug Abuse
Description: This course is a study of the etiology of alcohol and drug abuse, various types of addictive substances, physical,  mental and social implications, programs in rehabilitation, and preventive education.

Title: Case Management
Description: This course covers accepted methods and strategies for effectively assessing client needs, accessing necessary provider agencies, monitoring and properly documenting service delivery and client welfare.

Title: Behavior Change Techniques
Description: This course is a study of major theories associated with  individual and group psychotherapy, family therapy, and alcohol, drug, and vocational rehabilitation. Emphasis is placed on the techniques of behavioral change.

Title: Personal/Interpersonal Adjustment
Description: This course is the study of self-awareness and interpersonal adjustment and behavior in contemporary society.

Title: Interviewing Techniques
Description: This course covers  the development of skills necessary for interviews in various organizational settings. Students in Human Services will use these skills and knowledge later their supervised field placements.

Title: Counseling Techniques
Description: This course is a study of a variety of counseling techniques necessary to assist qualified therapists in a variety of therapeutic settings. Students will demonstrate procedures and knowledge of basic counseling theories and techniques related to Human Services.

Title: Group Dynamics
Description: This course is an examination of the theory and practice of group dynamics. Emphasis is on the application of the value and use of the group process in specialized settings related to Human Services.

Title: Crisis Intervention
Description: This course is a study of the effects of a crisis on people, the methods of intervention, and other use of multiple resources to re-establish individual functioning. Students are required to demonstrate mock crisis activities.

Title: Personal and Career Assessment
Description: This course covers an in-depth examination of personal needs, wants, values, strengths, abilities, and interests of an individual. Multiple inventories and evaluation strategies allow the student to evaluate and apply individual data to a personal career choice.

Title: LINUX Essentials
Description: This course will provide students with the fundamental knowledge and concepts of the LINUX operating system, including command line functions, file systems, user and group administration, process management, text editors, and network applications.

Title: LINUX Security Administration
Description: This course will provide students with the skills necessary to implement and administer basic LINUX security policies, including authentication, securing network applications, system monitoring, encryption, and others. 196

Title: Data Communications
Description: This course is a study of the fundamentals of data communications. Basic signaling, networking, and various transmission media are covered. Prerequisite:  CPT 101

Title: Local Area Networks
Description: This course is a study of the methods used to interconnect computers, terminals, word processors, facsimile and other office machines within a given area. Examples of vendor  implementations are used to illustrate various approaches. Prerequisite:  IST 220

Title: Computer Forensics
Description: This course provides students with a foundational knowledge in computer forensics investigation.  Students are introduced to the skills, tools, and methods used to gather, document, and handle electronic evidence.

Title: Fundamentals of Network Security I
Description: This course is the study of intro levels of security processes based on a security policy, emphasizing hands-on skills in the areas of secure perimeter, security connectivity, security management, identity services, and intrusion detection.  The course prepares students to manage network security.

Title: Fundamentals of Network Security II
Description: This course is the study of advanced security processes based on a security policy, emphasizing hands-on skills in the areas of secure perimeter, security, and intrusion detection. The course prepares students to install/configure secure firewalls. Prerequisite: IST 291

Title: IT and Data Assurance I
Description: The course introduces the basics of network security.  Topics covered will include network vulnerabilities and threats, security planning, security technology, network security organization, as well as legal and ethical issues related to network security.

Title: IT and Data Assurance II
Description: This course introduces methods for attacking a network, concepts, principles, tools, and techniques for attacking and disabling a network will be covered in the context of understanding how to properly secure a network as a network administrator.

Title: Developmental Mathematics
Description: Developmental Mathematics includes a review of arithmetic skills and focuses on the study of measurement and geometry, basic algebra concepts, and data analysis. Application skills are emphasized.

Title: Beginning Algebra
Description: This course includes the following topics:  operations with signed numbers; addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division with algebraic expressions; factoring; techniques for solving linear and fractional equations; and an introduction to graphing.

Title: Intermediate Algebra
Description: This course includes the following topics:  properties of numbers; fundamental operations with algebraic expressions; polynomials; systems of equations, ratios and proportion; factoring; functions; graphs; solutions of linear inequalities; and linear and quadratic equations. Prerequsite:  MAT 101

Title: Introduction to College Algebra
Description: This course includes mathematical methods, problem solving, operations with real numbers, variable expressions, polynomials, factoring, solving simple fractional, linear, and quadratic equations and inequalities, graphing, systems of equations and functions. 197

Title: College Algebra
Description: This course includes the following topics:  polynomial, rational, logarithmic, and exponential functions; inequalities; systems of equations and inequalities; matrices; determinants; simple linear programming; solutions of higher degree polynomials; combinatorial algebra, including the binomial theorem; and introduction to probability. Prerequisite:  MAT 102

Title: College Trigonometry
Description: This course includes the following topics: circular functions; trigonometric identities; solution of right and oblique triangles; solution of trigonometric equations, polar coordinates, and complex numbers, including Demoivre’s Theorem; vectors; conic sections; sequences; and series. Prerequisite:  MAT 110

Title: Elementary Calculus
Description: This course includes the following topics: differentiation and integration of polynomials; rational, logarithmic, and exponential function; and interpretation and application of these processes. Prerequisite:  MAT 110

Title: Analytical Geometry and Calculus I
Description: This course includes the following topics: continuation of calculus of one variable, including analytic geometry, techniques of integration, volumes by integration, and other applications; infinite series, including Taylor series and improper integrals. Prerequisite: MAT 110

Title: Analytical Geometry and Calculus II
Description: This course includes the following topics: continuation of calculus of one variable, including analytic geometry, techniques of integration, volumes by integration, and other applications; infinite series, including Taylor series and improper integrals. Prerequisite: Analytical Geometry and Calculus I

Title: Contemporary Mathematics
Description: This course includes techniques and applications of the following topics: elementary number theory; algebra; geometry; measurement; graph sketching and interpretations; and descriptive statistics.

Title: Calculus
Description: This course includes the following topics: differentiation and integration of polynomial and rational functions with applications of these processes.

Title: Geometry
Description: This course includes the following topics: Euclidean geometry of points, lines, triangles, circles, and polygons; right triangle trigonometry; and analytical geometry of the straight line. (This course is designed primarily for elementary teachers.)

Title: Fluid Mechanics
Description: This course is a study of the physical properties of fluids and includes hydrostatics, buoyancy, flow of incompressible fluids, orifices, venturis, and nozzles.

Title: Machine Design
Description: This course covers the design and application of machine elements such as shafts, couplings, springs, brakes, clutches, gears, and bearings. It also covers the applications of the principles of DC/AC statics, strength of materials, engineering drawing and dynamics to the design of simple machines.

Title: Principles of Management
Description: This course is a study of management theories, emphasizing the management functions of planning, decision making, organizing, leading, and controlling. 198

Title: Small Business Management
Description: This course is a study of small business management and organization, forms of ownership, and the process of starting a new business.

Title: Marketing
Description: This course covers an introduction to the field of marketing with a detailed study of the marketing concept and the processes of product development, pricing, promotion, and marketing distribution.

Title: Retailing
Description: This course is a study of the importance of retailing in American business and covers the concepts of store location, layout, merchandising, display, pricing, inventory control, promotional programs and profit management.

Title: Sales Principles
Description: This course is a study of the personal selling process with special emphasis on determining customer needs and developing effective communications and presentation skills.

Title: Customer Service Techniques
Description: This course is a study of the techniques and skills required for providing customer service excellence, including illustrations to turn customer relations into high standards of customer service, satisfaction, and repeat sales.

Title: Masonry Fundamentals
Description: This course is an introduction to masonry skills and tools.

Title: Chorus I
Description: This course includes the study and performance of selected choral music.

Title: Chorus II
Description: This course includes the study and performance of selected choral music.

Title: Chorus III
Description: This course includes the study and performance of selected choral music.

Title: Chorus IV
Description: This course includes the study and performance of selected choral music.

Title: Music Appreciation
Description: This course is an introduction to the study of music with focus on the elements of music and their relationships, the musical characteristics of representative works and composers, common musical forms and genres of various western and non-western historical style periods, and  appropriate listening experiences.

Title: Music Fundamentals
Description: This course is an introduction to the elements of music and music notation with keyboard applications.

Title: Physical Science I
Description: This is the first of a sequence of courses in physical science and includes an introduction to science with emphasis on science terminology and investigations of the physical world. Topics are selected from astronomy, chemistry, geology, and physics.

Title: Physical Science II
Description: This course is a continuation of the introduction to science with emphasis on science terminology and investigations of the physical world. Topics are selected from astronomy, chemistry, geology, and physics.

Title: Physics I
Description: This is the first in a sequence of Physics courses. Topics include mechanics, wave motion, sound, heat, electromagnetism, optics, and modern physics. 199

Title: Fundamentals of Nursing
Description: This course introduces basic principles and beginning skills necessary to the nursing process. Concepts are integrated relating to physiological, psychosocial, nutrition and health and safety needs of the individual. Legal and ethical roles of the practical nurse are emphasized.

Title: Medical-Surgical Nursing I
Description: This course is the beginning study utilizing the nursing process. Concepts include physiological, psychosocial, nutrition and health and safety needs of the adult. Clinical experiences address commonly occurring health problems having predictable outcomes.

Title: Pharmacology
Description: This course is an introductory course to the concepts of pharmacology and medication administration. Emphasis is on calculation of dosages, administration of medications and correct use of abbreviations. Effects of specific drugs are presented.

Title: Medical-Surgical Nursing II
Description: This course is a continuation of the study of the nursing process. Concepts include physiological, psychosocial, nutritional, health and safety needs of the adult. Clinical experiences address selected commonly occurring health problems having predictable outcomes.

Title: Medical-Surgical Nursing III
Description: This course is a continuation of the study of the nursing process. Concepts include physiological, psychosocial, nutritional, health and safety needs of the adult. Clinical experiences address selected commonly occurring health problems having predictable outcomes.

Title: Nursing Care of the Family
Description: This course focuses on nursing care of the family during childbearing and childrearing. Clinical sites may include both acute and community settings.

Title: Nursing Care of the Older Adult
Description: This course is a continuation of the study of the nursing process. Concepts include physiological, psychosocial, nutrition and health and safety needs of the older adult. Clinical experiences address commonly occurring health problems having predictable outcomes.

Title: American Government
Description: This course is a study of national governmental institutions with emphasis on the Constitution, the functions of the executive, legislative and judicial branches, civil liberties, and the role of the electorate.

Title: General Psychology
Description: This course includes the following topics and concepts in the science of behavior: scientific methods, biological basis for behavior, perception, motivation, learning memory, development, personality, abnormal behavior, therapeutic techniques, and social psychology.

Title: Human Growth and Development
Description: This course is a study of the physical, cognitive, and social factors affecting human growth, development, and potential. Prerequisite: PSY 201

Title: Developmental Reading
Description: This course is an intensive review of the academic reading skills needed for success in a college-level course. Students will demonstrate their understanding of reading as a process and will apply strategies learned to expand their reading comprehension skills.  Students will demonstrate the ability to integrate knowledge, use context clues, and identify supporting details.

Title: Introduction to Sociology
Description: 200 This course emphasizes the fundamental concepts and principles of sociology, including culture, socialization, interaction, social groups and stratification, effects of population growth, and technology in society and social institutions.

Title: Juvenile Delinquency
Description: This course presents the nature, extent, and causes of juvenile delinquency behavior, including strategies used in the prevention, intervention, and control of deviant behavior. Prerequisite:  SOC 101

Title: Ethnicity and Minority Issues
Description: This course is a sociological study of social and technological changes influencing minority and ethnic issues.

Title: Sociology of the Family
Description: This course includes an application of theory and research related to family behaviors, roles and values with emphasis on understanding family problems. Prerequisite:  SOC 101

Title: Elementary Spanish
Description: This course is a study of the four basic language skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing, including an introduction to Hispanic cultures.

Title: Elementary Spanish II
Description: This course continues development of the basic language skills and the study of Hispanic cultures. Prerequisite: SPA 101

Title: Intermediate Spanish I
Description: This course is a review of Spanish grammar with attention given to more complex grammatical structures and reading difficult prose. Prerequisite: SPA 102

Title: Public Speaking
Description: This course is an introduction to principles of public  speaking with application of speaking skills.

Title: Introduction to Theatre
Description: This course includes the appreciation and analysis of theatrical literature, history, and production.

Title: Introduction to Welding
Description: This course covers the principles of welding, cutting, and basic procedures for safety in using welding equipment.

Title: Print Reading I
Description: This is a basic course which includes the fundamentals of print reading, the meaning of lines, views, dimensions, notes, specifications, and structural shapes. Welding symbols and assembly drawings as used in fabrication work are also covered.

Title: Gas Welding and Cutting
Description: This course covers gas welding, brazing, soldering, and cutting of metals.

Title: Gas and ARC Welding
Description: This course covers the basic principles and practices of oxyacetylene welding, cutting, and electric welding.  Emphasis is placed on practice in fundamental position welding and safety procedures.

Title: Gas Metal ARC Welding I
Description: This course covers equipment setup and the fundamental techniques for welding ferrous and non-ferrous metals.

Title: ARC Welding I
Description: This course covers the safety, equipment, and skills used in the shielded metal arc welding process. Fillet welds are made to visual criteria in several positions. 201

Title: ARC Welding II
Description: This course is a study of welding of ferrous and/or non-ferrous metals.

Title: Advanced Inert Gas Welding
Description: This course covers the techniques for all positions of welding ferrous and non-ferrous metals.

Title: Weld Quality
Description: This is an introductory course in weld quality assurance.

Title: Pipefitting and Welding
Description: This is a basic course in fitting and welding pipe joints, either ferrous or non-ferrous, using standard processes. 202
